Posted: June 15, 2014
												The Swapper is an interesting puzzle platformer with some new ideas and a very suitable space ambience. You are a lone spaceman landing on a strange ship/planet and besides running and jumping just have an alien device "the swapper". With this  "weapon", you can create up to 4 clones of yourself that move exactly the same way as you. But you can not only use those clones to activate platform switches, you can swap yourself between those clones by pointing at a clone and "fire" your swapper device. You basically have to find and get lots of "orbs" to escape the planet.As long as just a clone of you dies, you can always recreate the clone. You can always swap between clones that you can reach with the swapper, even though you are just falling. This leads e.g. to the ability to "fly" just by creating clones anywhere in the room. Outside of the stations, you can also float and your swapper device is like a little rocket to push off. There are also gravity changers to walk on the ceiling. The puzzles are not too hard but there are some of them that really requires you to think in other dimensions.This nice twist for a puzzler is supported by a deep athmospheric surrounding with rare soft space music in the background, "dirty" graphics especially outside, radio voice signals with acoustic noise, and some challanging puzzles with absorbing lights, gravity and ... clones.Good game but not too chalanging. By the way: the achievements do not work in the Linux version, so far.

Posted: March 9, 2014
												tl;dr at the bottom.I just finished this game in one sitting (somewhere between 4 and 5 hours) and I can definitely recommend it. It's a little short, however, it's also a good puzzle game so it's definitely forgiveable. Each puzzle felt unique in some way, and while there was never too many mechanics at once, it does increase the complexity along the way. The difficulty was actually about perfect for me, I got stuck on 2 puzzles but ended up being able to solve them without a walkthrough. I wouldn't say it was an easy game at all, but the difficulty scales up at a healthy rate so solving puzzles is generaly satisfying but you shouldn't feel out of your depth. For the mostpart, platforming isn't as much of a focus as the puzzle solving, and with the ability to slow time you shouldn't feel put off if you're not a great platform jumper.The atmosphere is  great, and the story is interesting if a little understated. Most of the backstory will come through computer logs and it will require a bit of piecing the parts together. If you read them, you should have a fairly good idea of what's going on by the end of the game, and there's plenty of gaps left for you to decide some of the finer details on your own. The graphics and the sound seem designed to compliment said atmosphere, and the clay animations and ambient sound does a great job.tl;dr: Well balanced puzzle game, great atmosphere, definitely worth a purchase. If you're a bit broke and  looking for money/time you might want to wait for a sale, but I can assure you it's a good quality game so buying at full price shouldn't disappoint you.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												I kept rehashing my thoughts on this game, because I didn't want to jump to high up in my favorite games so quickly. I felt I had to keep thinking about it, because obviously an indie like this shouldn't be one of my favorite games, right?Well, it is. This is one of the best games I've played. I'm not going to say much more than that. I just want to highlight to the two things (well, two and a half) that stand out to me.First, are the puzzles. The start off fairly simple, but they teach you as you go. It's important to point out that you don't unlock any new abilities in this game. You have your swapper gun and that's it. That being said, it's a puzzle system that I've never seen before. The game knows this might be confusing for new players. As such, the first several puzzles are set up to teach you different techniques. They don't just display text on the screen and say "do it this way." They give you just enough clues to help you think outside the box. By the end of the game, there are some head scratchers. Nothing impossible, but some great designs that put your new thinking to the test.Second is the atmosphere. I don't think I've played a game that oozes more atmosphere than The Swapper. From the opening scene until the end, when I wasn't focused on the puzzle at hand, I was just in awe. Just through simple music and art, the game really transports you to another place. Without giving too much away, there some zero g moments in the game, and they just feel inspired. Those moments are surreal and they'll definitely be in my mind for a while.The story of the game is also quite interesting. It's done in a way that it leaves a lot of interpretation up to the player, so I won't go into much detail there; I'll just say that there are a few quite thought-provoking scenes.Anyway, so if you like puzzle games, or games dripping with atmosphere, check it out. I finished it in about 5 hours.

												The Swapper is a nice little puzzle game very similar to Portal where you are put in the shoes of an astronaut who has a swapper device. This device allows you to create (with a right click) upto five different clones of yourself that mimick your every movement and to swap your mind with any one of them with a left click. Your job is to collect enneagon orbs that allow you tp progress further in the game. Each such orb is in a puzzle room where there are obstacles, as well as strategically placed red light (prevents transferring your mind to clones in that area) and/or blue light (prevents creating clones in that area). Your clones cannot claim enneagon orbs, only you can. So your job is to figure out a way to get to the orb yourself in order to collect it, using your clones as pawns. The game is about 5-6 hours long and some of the puzzles are really tough nuts to crack but most are simple enough for even the casual gamer to figure it out pretty quick. The most interesting part of this game is its story - it is kinda creepy and unsettling and the atmosphere of the huge space station you are in is nicely done. Oh and the soundtrack is hauntingly beautiful, too. A four, out of five stars.

Posted: February 1, 2014
												This game is amazing. The game which consists of emotional and philosophical depth thematically is able to pull it off perfectly.The gameplay is a puzzle platformer with interesting and intriguing puzzles that are solvable and frustrating but purely on a logical deduction side, you never feel cheated out of an outcome, only as though you couldn't see it clearly enough. That revelation is so satisfying that it compels you to try your best and to figure it out correctly.While the gameplay is the bread and butter of the game the story is amazing to follow and well paced. You are a human (gender doesn't matter here) who has appeared on Spaceship outpost Theseus with a device called The Swapper which allows you to clone and swap bodies with yourself. From there you have to figure out what happened to the crew, who is this mysterious lady on board the ship and why are these rocks talking to you.All of these by themselves could be boring or unoriginal or uninteresting but it's the themes that drives them all to be unified and they are all utilized in perfection. Themes such as isolation, identity, life & death, community, all play a part in establishing the world and the decisions you make as a character. While you are alone on the ship solving puzzles, are you truly alone while you have clones of yourself? How can you prove your own identity if who you really were died 10 swaps ago? The game rests with you, It took me a few days to beat this game but the in between time ruined me, I would be at work or on my way home either mentally going over a puzzle in my head or wondering if we were all clones or if the ship died of causes outside of the believed threat. The moral and philosophical implications made me question choice that I had made in my own life, and what it meant to be selfish or selfless. It's games likes these that I wished that more people would play in order to truly undertstand that videogames as a medium can be examples of high art. Posted: March 28, 2014
												For an Indie game, I expected to have just an ok game.  However, this puzzle/platformer sets itself apart as a stellar indie that in my opinion can be more entertaining than some popular franchise games.  First off, the game has simple mechanics and controls.  In the first 15 minutes you will have all the tools you need to solve any puzzle and journey throughout the environment.  Secondly, the game's atmosphere and story is really compelling and absorbing.  The creepy and unique environment (the art style is based off of clay animation and scavenged household objects) will have you hooked while the story will throw you a number of twists.  Finally, the game has no need for violence.  There are no enemies or gore and can be a good break from violent games.  The down side?  The Swapper may be a great game but it can try your patience.  Numerous puzzles had me frustrated.  This could be a plus for those who crave puzzles,  but those with lesser patience will loathe the game.  Another aspect is the game length which is only 4.8 hours on my first playthrough.  This may be seen as a short story, but the game was worth it.  Other than that, I didn't find much fault with it.Overall, I strongly recommend this game.  I typically don't like puzzle games, but I found this one rewarding and worth the investment.

Posted: September 11, 2014
												If you like puzzle platformers, you must get this title. In this game, you rely on The Swapper, a device that lets you create copies of yourself and then teleport your conciousness into them. Puzzles then are solved using this mechanic.The mechanic:- Cloning: You can create up to 4 copies of yourself ( 5, including the original you ). Each copy won't stay still and will mimic what the original dude does, so plan ahead! You can create clones anywhere you want, as long as there is a direct line of sight- Conciousness / Mind transfer. You switch which individual is in control. This is useful when you need to get to hard-to-reach places. Also as far as you can, as long as there is a direct line of sight.- Merging: If you can corner a clone and physically touch it, the clone dissapears. This is useful when you need to reuse one of them.- Gravity switch: This comes later in the game. Gravity fields will make your guy to flip "upside-down", allowing you to jump and place clones on both sides of a platformThe obstacles: Besides hard walls, there are 2 main obstacles:- Blue light fields: You cannot make clones in places lit with blue light. You can transfer your mind into any clone that is already in there, however.- Red light fields. You cannot transfer your mind through them ( same as with hard walls ), but you can create clones in red light.- Purple light fields ( did I say only 2? ). It's a combination of blue and red lights.Other stuff:- Boxes: Pull and push to block lights and doors- Buttons: Step on them ( or place a clone ) to turn lights off or open doors- Teleporters: Fast jumping through the map- Zero gravity zones: This took me a few seconds to realize, but you need to shoot the Swapper to use as propulsion in these levels.- Orbs: You must collect these in the puzzle levels to move the story forward.- Slow-mo: When placing a new clone, the game will switch to slow motion. This is particularly useful to place clones while falling ( and then teleporting to the new clone to avoid death )The story is interesting, but in my opinion secondary to the game. The puzzles are more fun than the story :3My only complaints are that:- It's a bit short. You can clear it within 5 hours- The achievements are unintuitive. They're just numbers with no explanation of what to do. After doing some internet seraching, you have to go to hidden areas outside the screen to unlock them. Kind of defeats the point of being "achievements" if they're hidden, imo.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												The Swapper is a great puzzle platformer with some really nifty ideas and gameplay mechanics. As you progress through the game, you learn about what has happened to the station that you're in and the mystery begins to reveal itself. The story is also fairly well developed and kinda heavy too touching on question of life, the universe, and everything. =)The controls are simple - With WASD, you move left and right, have the ability to jump, and are able to grab blocks in some of the puzzles. The mechanics of the Swapper device are simple to understand: you are able to create 5 clones, and you can swap to them. The clones maintain their orientation as the were created, and imitate the movements of the 'active' clone. The concept is simple, but quickly becomes very difficult to master in some of the later puzzles.The game is visually stunning; the art is beautiful. From what I've read about it, the developers molded most of the game assets in clay and then imaged them into the game. This creates the unique look that The Swapper has. The music is grade-A and very beautiful to listen to. Along with the art, it sets the mood of the game as a gloomy, lonely, yet inquisitive environment.And the ending. Wow. There are two endings available. One is kinda meh, but the other one really wraps up the whole experience.As for the cons... the game was a bit short, unfortunately. I would say I logged about 5 hours of gameplay. Of course, your mileage will vary depending on the puzzles and how quickly you get through them. There's also achievements, however, I have no idea what they are. I've beaten the game, and haven't unlocked even one. They are titled as Roman numerals and the description is the same as the title, so there's no hint as to what they are. The game also has no replayability at all.However, those are my only real gripes, and definitely doesn't offset from the great playing experience this game has to offer. I wholly recommend it, 9/10.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												I kept rehashing my thoughts on this game, because I didn't want to jump to high up in my favorite games so quickly. I felt I had to keep thinking about it, because obviously an indie like this shouldn't be one of my favorite games, right?Well, it is. This is one of the best games I've played. I'm not going to say much more than that. I just want to highlight to the two things (well, two and a half) that stand out to me.First, are the puzzles. The start off fairly simple, but they teach you as you go. It's important to point out that you don't unlock any new abilities in this game. You have your swapper gun and that's it. That being said, it's a puzzle system that I've never seen before. The game knows this might be confusing for new players. As such, the first several puzzles are set up to teach you different techniques. They don't just display text on the screen and say "do it this way." They give you just enough clues to help you think outside the box. By the end of the game, there are some head scratchers. Nothing impossible, but some great designs that put your new thinking to the test.Second is the atmosphere. I don't think I've played a game that oozes more atmosphere than The Swapper. From the opening scene until the end, when I wasn't focused on the puzzle at hand, I was just in awe. Just through simple music and art, the game really transports you to another place. Without giving too much away, there some zero g moments in the game, and they just feel inspired. Those moments are surreal and they'll definitely be in my mind for a while.The story of the game is also quite interesting. It's done in a way that it leaves a lot of interpretation up to the player, so I won't go into much detail there; I'll just say that there are a few quite thought-provoking scenes.Anyway, so if you like puzzle games, or games dripping with atmosphere, check it out. I finished it in about 5 hours.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Where was this on everybody’s “2013 game of the year” list?? As of this writing, it’s January 2014, so all of the major game websites have put out their “best games of 2013 list”. I’ve checked most of the major gaming websites, and this game has appeared on precisely none of the “best game” lists, whereas games like Brothers and Bioshock Infinite - both of which I found to be less than favorable - appear all over the place. I don’t understand. Anyway, The Swapper is an indie puzzle game which has taken quite a bit of influence in its art direction from the Metroid games. Actually, this game threw me quite a bit at first. After seeing all of the visual and stylistic references to Metroid, I was expecting a Metroidvania game. The Swapper is very much just a puzzle game and nothing more, but it’s a very good puzzle game. The main puzzle solving mechanic in the game is the title device, The Swapper. It allows the user to make clones of themselves that will mimic the user’s actions one to one. It also allows the user to transfer their consciousness not only between their clones, but between any living being, which makes for some interesting storytelling. Armed with The Swapper, you’ll explore a derelict space station that has been seemingly mysteriously abandoned. You’ll solve puzzles and read crew logs to try to piece together what happened to the station. The puzzle design in this game was pretty excellent, on par with games like Portal or Braid, where I would just stare at the screen for minutes at a time and try to think through what I needed to do to complete the puzzle. Light plays an important role in this game’s puzzles. Blue light will block The Swapper’s cloning feature where red light will block the “swapping” feature. Purple light will block both. The game’s mechanics are a bit difficult to illustrate verbally, so you may want to check out some gameplay videos to get the idea and see if this interests you. Don’t be thrown by the Metroid references, this isn’t that kind of game. But if you enjoy puzzle games, The Swapper is a must-play.For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

												The Swapper is a succinct little puzzle game about the ability to create clones and (as you might expect) swap your consciousness with them. This is done through a gun-like device similar to Portal and like Portal it uses its limited mechanics to great effect. The two main wrinkles in the puzzles are that all the clones move and jump to the same input and various types of light create areas that block either the clone creation or swapper functions of your device. This means it is a game primarily about relative motion and line of sight. Moving your clones around can be a bit like herding cats, so you have to think several steps ahead to get everyone where they need to be. The story deals with the nature of consciousness and a race of sentient rocks, but it is mostly a curiosity to break up the puzzle rooms. The game has a rather dark atmosphere supported directly by its mechanics (your clones rarely meet a happy end). I recommend The Swapper if you enjoy having your mind fried wrapping your head around situations that appear impossible.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												The Swapper combines flawless mechanics, an otherworldy aesthetic and a haunting narrative into not only one of the best puzzle games on the market, but one of the best games available period. In The Swapper, you control a faceless, voiceless, nameless protagonist. This is a deliberate choice, considering that the Swapper Device, the game's mechanical hook, allows you to create up to four clones (meaning five bodies total) at a time for you to swap your consciousness between. What exactly this consciousness is (a soul?), the game never elucidates, and rightly so. This is a game of worrying questions and previous few answers.There are also environmental obstacles, such as pitfalls, specific areas that prohibit creating clones/swapping/both, and gravity switches. The gameplay objectives consist of rooms with an "orb" at the end, which must be picked up by a body you are inhabiting for it to count towards your overall collection. In order to reach the incredible ending, one must collect them all; so while you can leave a room before you complete it, be aware that you will always have to come back to it eventually. The simplicity of these mechanics makes them fantastically compelling. I often feel compelled to look up a walkthrough in some games, because I think I'm missing something and don't like looking for answers in the wrong place. This is avoided completely in The Swapper, as the rooms are clearly set-out and all important aspects of the puzzle are made clear and highlighted. This results in fine, fine logic puzzles that tease but do not baffle. This is a game that makes you respect the craft of the puzzles enough that you don't want to look up a walkthrough. You may get frustrated at points - trust me, I was - but the ability to drop out of a puzzle any time and go looking for more completely negates that.The atmosphere of the game is perfect. The desaturated tones and harsh, hyper-real lighting created by the combination of found objects and claymation mean that the aesthetic of the game is bleakly beautiful. The organic and synthetic alike are rendered with such incredible detail and moody truth that you'd swear you're exploring real locations. The murky greys and hospital whites are only broken by items you can interact with, and this is purposeful, I feel: they are the only vestiges of life and hope left in an otherwise dead ship. The sound design, too, is phenomenal. The thuds, scrapes and clangs of space are all captured with the same muted distance the rest of the aesthetic champions, and the result is a slow, hard, weighty feel to the movement and environments of the game. The soundtrack is beautifully eerie and occasionally offers a reprise from the bleakness. It reminds me very much of the film Moon, and though that is perhaps an obvious comparison, there is a reason for that.I will do my best to recommend the story without spoiling much for you, but if the rest of the review is enough that you already want to buy the game, I still recommend you skip this paragraph. That said, this game communicates existential dread and the terror of mortality like no other I have played, and does so through perfect fusion of the mechanics and narrative themes. It presents a world and characters that should be dead, but do not want to die. They exist purely through will and determination, and they are not the better for it. Everyone is a frantic husk, and everyone is looking to buy more time. There are text logs, but they simply fill in the fairly interesting lore - the real bulk of the writing's strength comes from other sources. It is frightening and meditative, and makes one stop and think. To say any more would be a disservice.The game is not perfect, though, as no games are. Some of the voice acting is slightly iffy (though never strictly bad), and the fast, jerky movement speed, while perfect for puzzles, undermines some of the more resonant moments of the narrative. These are, however, minor faults in an otherwise incredible game.I would suggest The Swapper to everyone who enjoys puzzle games and/or strong narratives, but that would be fairly useless. To summarise, I would say that the game is a graceful, poignant example of the beauty and horror of perspective. And that, in a two-dimensional game, is something.

I wouldn't say it was an easy game at all, but the difficulty scales up at a healthy rate so solving puzzles is generaly satisfying but you shouldn't feel out of your depth. For the mostpart, platforming isn't as much of a focus as the puzzle solving, and with the ability to slow time you shouldn't feel put off if you're not a great platform jumper.The atmosphere is  great, and the story is interesting if a little understated. Most of the backstory will come through computer logs and it will require a bit of piecing the parts together. If you read them, you should have a fairly good idea of what's going on by the end of the game, and there's plenty of gaps left for you to decide some of the finer details on your own. The graphics and the sound seem designed to compliment said atmosphere, and the clay animations and ambient sound does a great job.tl;dr: Well balanced puzzle game, great atmosphere, definitely worth a purchase. If you're a bit broke and  looking for money/time you might want to wait for a sale, but I can assure you it's a good quality game so buying at full price shouldn't disappoint you.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												I kept rehashing my thoughts on this game, because I didn't want to jump to high up in my favorite games so quickly. I felt I had to keep thinking about it, because obviously an indie like this shouldn't be one of my favorite games, right?Well, it is. This is one of the best games I've played. I'm not going to say much more than that. I just want to highlight to the two things (well, two and a half) that stand out to me.First, are the puzzles. The start off fairly simple, but they teach you as you go. It's important to point out that you don't unlock any new abilities in this game. You have your swapper gun and that's it. That being said, it's a puzzle system that I've never seen before. The game knows this might be confusing for new players. As such, the first several puzzles are set up to teach you different techniques. They don't just display text on the screen and say "do it this way." They give you just enough clues to help you think outside the box. By the end of the game, there are some head scratchers. Nothing impossible, but some great designs that put your new thinking to the test.Second is the atmosphere. I don't think I've played a game that oozes more atmosphere than The Swapper. From the opening scene until the end, when I wasn't focused on the puzzle at hand, I was just in awe. Just through simple music and art, the game really transports you to another place. Without giving too much away, there some zero g moments in the game, and they just feel inspired. Those moments are surreal and they'll definitely be in my mind for a while.The story of the game is also quite interesting. It's done in a way that it leaves a lot of interpretation up to the player, so I won't go into much detail there; I'll just say that there are a few quite thought-provoking scenes.Anyway, so if you like puzzle games, or games dripping with atmosphere, check it out. I finished it in about 5 hours.

The ending, sadly, does not leave you with any answers, though perhaps that is a good thing. Posted: February 23, 2014
												I just completed the game 100% and I thought the 5 1/2 hours of playtime was well worth it. (Note: This review contains a very minor gameplay spoiler that I think is worth mentioning, so if that bothers you, stop reading this). Many people consider this game to be a "metroidvania" style game, but I honestly wouldn't consider it to be one because of three reasons: 1) The game consists of many, many "green" rooms, all of which are puzzles of increasing difficulty. I liked the feeling of progression but felt like some of the last few (possibly optional?) puzzles were overly complicated. I couldn't figure out how to "properly" solve them and I never referred to a walkthrough, but I did notice that each "clone" you made would have about a 1-frame delay from your "main" character's actions. This allows you to abuse your jump and disintegrate a clone that you couldn’t otherwise touch.2) I felt like the game was very linear despite its open-world style layout. I guess you could say the same about Metroid in terms of playing the game casually (without sequence breaking), but this game evoked a feeling of linearity unlike the Metroid and SotN-inspired Castlevania games.3) Your character has limited abilities. Spoiler: There are no weapon or suit upgrades that you encounter throughout the game. The environments change and different game mechanics are introduced, but the main character never gains a new ability.Ultimately, if you like puzzle and thought-provoking games, I'd highly recommend The Swapper. The story keeps things fairly interesting and, despite 2 or 3 puzzles that the game throws at you near the end, I think most of the puzzles are well-done and gradually become more difficult. Every puzzle requires a different approach than the last, so be prepared to get stuck a few times throughout the game.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												The Swapper is a great puzzle platformer with some really nifty ideas and gameplay mechanics. As you progress through the game, you learn about what has happened to the station that you're in and the mystery begins to reveal itself. The story is also fairly well developed and kinda heavy too touching on question of life, the universe, and everything. =)The controls are simple - With WASD, you move left and right, have the ability to jump, and are able to grab blocks in some of the puzzles. The mechanics of the Swapper device are simple to understand: you are able to create 5 clones, and you can swap to them. The clones maintain their orientation as the were created, and imitate the movements of the 'active' clone. The concept is simple, but quickly becomes very difficult to master in some of the later puzzles.The game is visually stunning; the art is beautiful. From what I've read about it, the developers molded most of the game assets in clay and then imaged them into the game. This creates the unique look that The Swapper has. The music is grade-A and very beautiful to listen to. Along with the art, it sets the mood of the game as a gloomy, lonely, yet inquisitive environment.And the ending. Wow. There are two endings available. One is kinda meh, but the other one really wraps up the whole experience.As for the cons... the game was a bit short, unfortunately. I would say I logged about 5 hours of gameplay. Of course, your mileage will vary depending on the puzzles and how quickly you get through them. There's also achievements, however, I have no idea what they are. I've beaten the game, and haven't unlocked even one. They are titled as Roman numerals and the description is the same as the title, so there's no hint as to what they are. The game also has no replayability at all.However, those are my only real gripes, and definitely doesn't offset from the great playing experience this game has to offer. I wholly recommend it, 9/10.

Posted: October 1, 2015
												The Swapper is quite simply a beautiful game. The gorgeous visuals, all hand crafted from clay and other household materials, immerse the player in a fully realised sci-fi universe. The atmosphere created by the both the art style and the minimalistic piano based soundtrack is intoxicating. You arrive on a space station, and are shortly contacted by another sole survivor who speaks of the existential nature of the human soul and how we define our sense of self. In the final moments of the game you will be asked to make a choice that, once made will likely leave you deep in thought for some time. The core game-play involves puzzles that gradually increase in difficulty, often quite sophisticated and intricate, making it all the more satisfying when you get it right. The player wields a device which can create clones of yourself and then swap your soul between them, this is the fundamental element in the puzzle mechanics. The puzzles are fun but what sets this game apart from others of the same genre is the world created by Facepalm games. This is a great example of how the medium of video games can offer something as emotionally rich and affecting as the great works of cinema and fiction writing.

												The Swapper is quite a fun adventure if you can tolerate it that is.The Swapper involves being on a abanonded spaceship vessel armed only with a machine that allows you to create clones and swap between them opening up some ingenious puzzle gameplay involving moving your clones to different locations etc not much can compare to killing off a whole legion of yourself from dropping down a large fall then crowning yourself king because your the only one with free will or creating and switching to one of your clones to save yourself from a nasty death.The puzzles in the game genuinely seem well thought out and aren't gimicky or dull but frustrating enough that your gonna get a kick out of finishing them properly above all they are a general joy to complete and do feel as if they are testing your brain in the later ones. There aren't any enemies in the game but truthfully the Swapper doesn't need them to be challenging, it's one of those games that has taken a simple idea and flown with it exploring how best it can use it's concept like Portal has for example.The game is set out metroidvania style which means backtracking and exploring a lot but that's part of the fun of the game - exploring the spaceship and wondering what happened to it's inhabitants. Most of the story is told through small bits of texts that you can find throughout the game that help you to slowly piece together whatever the hell happened. On top of this all The Swapper's art style is pretty unique with the characters being made out of clay and shows that you don't have to be a big budget release to look great and atmospheric - I felt isloated and alone in the cold ship interior and started to long for another human being during the adventure. My only real problem with the Swapper would be the length and how (justifiably) annoying the puzzles can be, which can easily make you start to hate the game or get bored of it. That being said if your into both puzzles and adventuring the Swapper is a title your going to want to pick up.+ Atmospheric + Puzzles are well thought out+  Visuals are great+ Ingenious concept- Kind of short- Puzzles may make you want to rip your hair out or sell your soul for the answers9/10

												Gunpoint may have worked my brain pretty hard in some stages, but nothing tested my mind as much as The Swapper (well, perhaps Antichamber... but we'll get into that later).  The Swapper uses a limited amount of controls to craft some fiendish puzzles, similar to Portal.  Your character can move left and right, but the titular mechanic reveals itself in the way you can create clones of yourself in nearly any location, and with another click you can switch to that clone.  Levels gradually introduce other challenges, such as areas of light that do not allow clone creation or swapping (or both), some larger areas that have you treading familiar territory like a Metroid game, and gravity puzzles because why not.  Overall, I enjoyed the game (again with a surprisingly deep story), but I also didn't like how certain later stages basically only had one intended way of success that can take a long time to figure out.  Then again, those "Eureka" moments when you do figure out a solution after an hour is pretty great... until I realize I spent an hour playing one puzzle :(

												An excellent, atmospheric puzzler.  The surprisingly deep narrative ties in perfectly with the simple gameplay mechanics and unique presentation.  Particularly for a game with such a 'handcrafted' aesthetic, eveything feels remarkably tight.  The Swapper deserves additional bonus points if you're versed in philosophy, particularly philosophy of the mind.  Although this isn't really a horror experience, you are likely to find yourself deeply unsettled as you play (in a good way).The puzzles themselves, with the exception of a few of the final ones, aren't terribly taxing; but they still provide enough of a challenge to maintain the inertia of the experience.  This game could have been longer again by half and still held my interest.My one gripe would be that the achievements (which involve finding hidden terminals) felt like an artificial means of extending the play time.  Some of the achievement locations made intuitive sense / provided environmental clues, but others seemed to require the player to scour every edge of every room in the hope of stumbling upon a hidden area.  Ultimately, I ended up cheating and using a guide to find most of these.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												I was drawn to "The Swapper" by the interesting game mechanics - cloning and swapping, and the fact that is an indie title that looks good (not a lot of those around). After finishing the game I must say... I got a lot more than I bargained for.The puzzles are interesting and quite challenging, requiring you to master the art of "clone 'n' swap" to perfection. You don't have any enemies, there are no boss fights, there are no impossible tasks - you just have to get away from the space station. During the game you realize what "swapping" actually means from a philosophical standpoint - you clone and you swap souls with the clone - is that still you? Is it moral to just take over someone else's body, be it your clone? You must ask yourself at the very end of this "two-alternative-endings" game. My only regret is that I have to play throught the whole game again to play the "alternate" ending.Highly recommended.

Posted: October 4, 2013
												A lot of reviews of The Swapper talk about how your actions in the game will touch you on a deep emotional level. The action of effectively killing clones of yourself over and over just to proceed, the philosophical argument about who is the real you, are you you, or are you a clone? Does it matter?Rest assured, if like me you don't care about any of that stuff, and like me, you don't really see the appeal of games like Dear Esther or Gone Home, there is still an awful lot to like about this game.The puzzles are excellent from start to finish. There are some really difficult ones in there, but they're never unfair, and because the game doesn't punish you for trial and error, other than by having you restart the room you're in, it hardly ever gets frustrating.Then there are the graphics. The Swapper has a really unique style, perhaps somewhat similar to The Dream Machine, with some excellent lighting and particle effects which really make this game look fantastic.The story isn't bad either. Setting aside the aformentioned philosophical and emotional elements, there's still an interesting sci-fi tale going on in the background, and throughout the playthrough there's an excellent sense of mystery and isolation.The only real negative I can think of about The Swapper is that the achievements are terrible. All of them are for accessing terminals which are hidden in such obscure places that you wouldn't even come close to spotting even one of them on a normal playthrough.But that's a minor complaint in an otherwise excellent game, and most certainly one of the best in the puzzle genre, so I highly recommend you give it a try!9/10

Posted: January 14, 2014
												A great little puzzle platformer, with a surprisingly deep message.It is not every day you hear a game talk about the "great chain of being", or dealing with very profound spiritual ideas and eastern and western philosophy. If you have any of those interests, you'll probably catch them here and there in this game. I think it is brave to snuck it in a game, where probably most will never catch these ideas though. But, there is no coincidence that the "big face" looks like a certain "eastern religious" figure. And the "dialog" found in this game has loads of philosophy/spirituality.I also noted hints, pointing out how futile culture-wars really are, and that the arguement of "matter versus spirit" ultimately misses the point; none replaces the other, but they complete each other. I very much agree, how refreshing!But if you have absolutely no idea of what I am talking about, don't worry. You don't have to know any of these things to enjoy this excellent game. In a way, I think those ideas are the point of the game, but they are still sneaky enough that you might never care about it and just enjoy the game, which is totally fine. And you might still find the story and the questions intriguing. Even the game mechanics should make you ask some interesting questions. And of course I think this game can be rightly interpreted in many ways, which is even greater in my mind.A really intelligent game, whith at some times very difficult puzzles, although the overall experience is not too difficult.

Posted: July 10, 2015
												This was a fantastic indie puzzle game. It's got the gameplay of Limbo, the atmosphere of Dead Space, and the puzzle style of Portal. Really well done.Graphics: The whole setting is really dark and creepy. They really pulled off the abandoned spaceship look quite well. Gameplay: The platforming style is similar to Limbo, but the main game mechanic is as innovative and interesting as something like Portal. Basically, you can create "clones" of yourself with a cloning gun and can switch to control each of the clones. It's really interesting and there were some great puzzles, incorporating things like reversing gravity, boxes and pressure pads, and different areas where you can/can't create clones.Story: I was very pleased with the story. It brought up a lot of issues involving the killing of the clones and whether or not your "soul" is lost in the clones, etc. The voice acting and writing was pretty good as well. The story was only about 3 hours long, but I felt like they did all they could with the puzzles and ended it at a good time.Overall, a fantastic indie game with a very well executed game mechanic. If you enjoyed Limbo and Portal, you would surely enjoy this game. 9/10

Short version: Fun game, relatively short game, very little replay value. Highly linear gameplay and lock-out after the ending doesn't pair well with non-linear story-telling.Steam Achievements are unrewarding.I'm glad I played it, but also glad I got it at a much-reduced price ($2.99) when it was on sale. Long Version: Visually and aurally the game is fantastic. Lots of complaints about bugs/controllability in the forums, but I had no issues. The price tag on the game is for all the hard work that went into the shape and feel of it.In it's basic mechanics, The Swapper a pretty straightforward and fairly linear puzzle game. Some folks have branded it a "metroidvania" title, but it really isn't: you gain all the skills/tools/abilities you're going to gain in the first 5 rooms, so there's never any real limitations built into the game that would impose a need to backtrack. The only thing that could impose non-linearity on gameplay is if you get irritated at a puzzle and leave it temporarily to go solve another. You'll have to get back to it eventually, and when you do you'll be bringing all the same tools to the table as before.So, gameplay is fun and demanding the first time through, but fairly formulaic.The storyline comes in small doses as you work through the game. A lot of reviews have praised The Swapper for raising philosophical issues about personal identity and consciousness, but reviews rarely actually discuss it. I found the links to philosophy to be pretty heavy-handed. The medium here (a game) is perhaps novel, but the ideas in play are far from it. The guy who handled the narrative is Tom Jubert (FTL, Penumbra), and he clearly knows this: it's as if the storyline, characters, and dialogue were read off of a syllabus for Metaphysics of Mind 101 -- and the game cites the syllabus. Characters named "Chalmers" and "Dennett" bicker over the nature of consciousness (see David Chamers and Dan Dennett). The ship's name is the "Theseus" (see "The Ship of Theseus" problem). All this makes one wonder who the story is written for, exactly. Players unfamiliar with philosophy of mind may not see the not-so-subtle references here, and so won't read into the subtext that's carrying much of the weight. Players who have read the syllabus won't find it very novel. For anyone, a difficulty with the story is that it really only comes together clearly in the last 5-10 minutes of gameplay. After a lot of slow and piecemeal development, everything comes to a head, and you're finally able to do what you've been trying to do for hours of play -- so you dutifully race to the abrupt ending, getting heavy doses of information that alter the narrative dramatically. Then, maddeningly, after the ending you're locked out of the game and cannot go back into it to either (a) revisit bits of the story you've collected, now wisened by a deeper understanding of what's been going on or (b)  see the alternate ending  You have to start all over again. But since nothing in gameplay changes on the second run, it becomes a pretty unrewarding grind.One thing that might force you back into the game is that you've likely missed all 10 steam achievements on the first run. That's because the developers didn't provide any description of what the achievements are, they're just roman numerals. I honestly reached the ending of the game and thought "Oh, I must be about to complete chapter I, so I'll unlock achievement "I" in a second now and go on to chapter II -- that'd make sense, and could explain the high price of the game; there must be lots more content yet." Nope.  And when you do go track down the achievements, they add absolutely nothing to the game at all in terms of storyline or character or anything.  You get to read one-sided emails to the Theseus as they start their work, discover the Watchers, and lose contact with command. Very boring. So the game is gorgeous and makes for a fun afternoon. But I'm not sure it's worth all the hype. Get it on sale.

												Several reviewers have made a comparison between this game and Portal, and I'm heavily inclined to do the same.Portal was quite possibly, with the exception of its successor, one of my favorite games of all time. Upon completing the canonical story of both Portal and Portal 2, I must say that I felt a strange emptiness that wasn't really fulfilled until this game.This game is a masterpiece.The gameplay, if you know what it is, begs the question why everything would need to be rendered in 3D, models, lighting and all. Upon playing, you'll find that it's meticulously atmospheric, immersive even. The soundtrack is both ambient and enjoyable as musical pieces on their own, and there's both an intuitive and logical aspect to the puzzle solving. The deliberate manner in which the game is designed can only be considered masterful.While I was nearly entirely immersed, I couldn't help but take myself out of the experience from time to time simply to admire the game for its design and creation.Portal and The Swapper differ in the sense that Star Wars and Interstellar differ. One is more geared towards your entertaining, and even as my absolute favorite game of all time, Portal can feel rather superficial in comparison. It provoked emotions, sympathy for the characters while making me laugh and enjoy the puzzles. The Swapper feels larger in scope, is more cerebral and thought-provoking, and is completely serious.There are countless similarities between the two, however. If you liked Portal for the puzzle solving and would also like something a bit more abstract, perhaps slightly philosophical, I would highly recommend this incredibly well crafted piece, something more of an experience than a game.
